headline: Kyoto Fire Suspect Was Once Jailed for Armed Robbery
summary: A man suspected of starting a fire that killed 34 people at a Kyoto animation studio was once jailed for armed robbery and earlier this week threatened a neighbor with violence, according to the neighbor.

headline: U.S. Downed Iranian Drone With New System
summary: The U.S. brought down an Iranian drone this week near an American warship in the Strait of Hormuz by using new technology that had just been added to naval defenses, the latest move by the U.S. military to deploy more furtive measures against Iran, defense officials said.

headline: Equifax to Pay Around $700 Million Related to Data Breach
summary: The credit-reporting firm is nearing a deal to settle a slew of state and federal investigations into a 2017 data breach that exposed nearly 150 million Americans’ Social Security numbers and other personal information.

headline: Schlumberger Names New CEO as Shale Woes Persist
summary: Schlumberger named Olivier Le Peuch as its next chief executive, while the Houston oil-field-services company continues to suffer from a slowdown in spending by U.S. shale drillers.

headline: JPMorgan Chase, Netflix, Gannett: Stocks That Defined The Week
summary: Major stock indexes ended lower this past week as investors weighed signals of an interest-rate cut and mixed earnings results from some of America’s biggest companies.

headline: The Wages of Rent Control
summary: New York’s latest law, hardly a month old, is already chilling builders.

headline: We’re Having a Heat Wave
summary: Up and down the Eastern Seaboard and throughout the Midwest, people are seeking relief from what could be record-breaking temperatures.

summary: The White House and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi continued talks over how to pay for a two-year agreement to raise overall spending limits and at the same time raise the U.S. government’s borrowing limit.

headline: State Movie Subsidies Are a Flop

headline: ‘Family of Origin’ Review: When Did It All Go Wrong?
summary: C.J. Hauser’s latest work may be the most oddly enticing novel you will read this year, no matter how you feel about ducks, baseball, evolution, the state of our planet or the fate of our run-amok species.

headline: General Catalyst’s Ilan Stern Leaves to Helm WeWork CEO’s Family Office
summary: WeWork CEO Adam Neumann became wealthy by selling stock in his company. He has sold potentially hundreds of millions worth of shares in the startup, The Wall Street Journal previously reported. He also has invested in real estate and startups.

headline: Supply Surge Sends Overnight Rates Above 10-Year Yields
summary: The persistent supply of U.S. government debt flooding the bond market this year has done little to raise bond yields, except in the market for the shortest-term securities.

summary: A heat wave across a large swath of the U.S. is expected to bring something potentially worse than record temperatures: record-high low temperatures.

headline: Topshop Parent, Landlords Clash Over U.S. Assets

headline: Yes, Your Boss Can Spy on You
summary: With all of the new technology that employees use at the office, companies have a lot more data on what their workers are doing. It is now cheaper and easier than ever for employers to spy on them. Sarah Krouse explains what’s happening, and why there’s little you can do about it.

headline: Real Estate Startup VTS Names M&A-Savvy CFO After Reaching Unicorn Status

headline: PG&E Comes Out Against Elliott’s $30 Billion Restructuring Pitch

headline: Boston Fed’s Rosengren Says Recent Economic Developments Have Been Positive

summary: Recent events in Latin America prove that their own societies, not external intervention, will drive change.

headline: Prosecutors Are Asked Why Trump Wasn’t Indicted for Campaign Violations

summary: Alto’s 1952 municipal building, in central Finland, hasn’t served its intended purpose since 1993. Currently, a local resident gives tours and rents rooms through Airbnb.

headline: Paimio Sanatorium
summary: Aalto’s tuberculosis facility opened in southwestern Finland in 1933. It later served as a hospital and is now partially used as a children’s rehabilitation center. Last year its owner put it up for sale but found no suitable buyers, and a committee was established to devise a viable future for the building.

headline: Buzz Aldrin’s Moon Landing Watch Gets Spiffy Reissue

headline: Owl Rock’s IPO Boosts Niche Market
